review.title: Assessing the Reach and Impact of Game-Based Learning Approaches to Cultural Competency and Behavioural Change
review.abstract: As digital games continue to be explored as solutions to educational and behavioural challenges, the need for evaluation methodologies which support both the unique nature of the format and the need for comparison with other approaches continues to increase. In this workshop paper, a range of challenges are described related specifically to the case of cultural learning using digital games, in terms of how it may best be assessed, understood, and sustained through an iterative process supported by research. An evaluation framework is proposed, identifying metrics for reach and impact and their associated challenges, as well as presenting ethical considerations and the means to utilize evaluation outcomes within an iterative cycle, and to provide feedback to learners. Presenting as a case study a serious game from the Mobile Assistance for Social Inclusion and Empowerment of Immigrants with Persuasive Learning Technologies and Social Networks (MASELTOV) project, the use of the framework in the context of an integrative project is discussed, with emphasis on the need to view game-based learning as a blended component of the cultural learning process, rather than a standalone solution. The particular case of mobile gaming is also considered within this case study, providing a platform by which to deliver and update content in response to evaluation outcomes. Discussion reflects upon the general challenges related to the assessment of cultural learning, and behavioural change in more general terms, suggesting future work should address the need to provide sustainable, research-driven platforms for game-based learning content.

metadata.title: Assessing the Reach and Impact of Game-Based Learning Approaches to Cultural Competency and Behavioural Change

sections.text: Educational and behavioural challenges, the need for evaluation methods that support both the uniqueness of the format and the need for comparison with other approaches, continue to increase. This workshop paper describes a number of challenges related specifically to the case of cultural learning through digital games, with regard to how it can best be evaluated, understood and maintained through an iterative process supported by research. It proposes an evaluation framework that identifies metrics for reach and impact and associated challenges, as well as ethical considerations and means of utilising evaluation results within an iterative cycle, and provides feedback to learners. As a case study presentation of a serious game from the Mobile Assistance for Social Inclusion and Empowerment of Immigrants with Persuasive Learning Technologies and Social Networks (MASELTOV) Project, the use of the framework in the context of an integrative project is discussed, with the emphasis on the need for human learning as a cultural component.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Game-based learning has proven effective in a variety of contexts, including cultural learning [1]. However, as with any educational medium, differences in audience, context and representative medium require individual design considerations. This, in turn, poses a challenge in translating research findings that typically analyze the effectiveness of a single game into generalizable outcomes that can be incorporated into future designs. Section 2 describes, in addition to the specific challenges for the development of cultural competences, a number of assessment methodologies that are applied to digital learning games. This forms the basis for the framework proposed in Section 3, which seeks to reconcile the uniqueness of gameplay as a form of data collection with the need to provide validated research results that allow comparison with other forms of education. Application of this framework to the MASELTOV project is described in Section 4, along with an overview of the serious game developed and its role within the project.

sections.heading: 2. BACKGROUND
sections.text: In fact, most people who are able, are able, are able to determine for themselves what they want and what they want, are also able to determine for themselves, "he told the German Press Agency in an interview with" Welt am Sonntag ":" I don't think we will be able to change the world. "

sections.heading: 3. ASSESSMENT FRAMEWORK
sections.text: This section reflects the background of the previous section and proposes a valuation approach for digital games used to develop cultural competencies. First, it describes the two main objectives common to the interventions of reach and impact. Reach is considered in terms of the delivery and distribution of games, while Impact aims to consolidate the diversity of techniques identified in the previous section in order to provide a basis for proposing clear pathways that are suitable both for the development process of serious games and for the need to demonstrate effectiveness. Here, we consider two central assessment contexts: laboratory studies and deployment among end users. The latter raises a number of important ethical considerations, especially with regard to the informed consent mentioned in Section 3.3. The subsequent question, given that measures of reach and impact can be established, is how the research results can best be returned to both game authors to support the iterative development and the conclusions of the development and learning process itself based on Section 5 and the feedback of indicators.

sections.heading: 3.1 Reach
sections.text: For games aimed at generating general awareness, this may be sufficient; in many cases, however, games target marginalized or decoupled demographic groups. Laboratory evaluation is unlikely to be representative of these groups, since they are less likely to be involved in the research process or opt for studies. Player base surveys are a potential way to gain a better understanding of the reach, and can be stimulated by in-game rewards such as content or collectibles. Correlation, for example, of reported zip codes to evidence of multiple discrimination can be a means of gaining an understanding of players "socio-economic background without explicitly requiring a survey, although it must be conducted in an ethical manner that follows the principles outlined in Section 3.3. In the case of a game intended to allow immigrants to develop their cultural competences, as described in Section 4, it may also be possible to adjust the total number of users to the overall population.

sections.heading: 3.2 Impact
sections.text: Section 2 illustrates the variety of methods by which the game has evolved. It means a clear distinction between the evaluations in the development phase, which aims to gain an understanding of the effects of the game.

sections.heading: 3.3 Ethical Considerations
sections.text: While ethical principles and practices can be relatively easily adhered to in a laboratory environment, as the researcher has direct contact with the participants to ensure informed consent, research with online audiences can prove to be a more complex issue. Consensus information can be overlooked or "clicked through" in the desire for the player to experience the game, so one design requirement is that consent should be given in an opt-in manner, with the player able to fully verify the implications of his consent. Since games per se can provide incentives to play, there is also a risk that players will agree to access the game rather than in an informed and ethical manner. Therefore, another endorsement is that access to the game should be granted regardless of a player's consent to participate in the research process. In the case of cultural learning and skill development, members of the target group may also have limited language skills, and consent approaches should demonstrate awareness and support for communicating research goals and the implications of participating with those players.

sections.heading: 3.4 Implementation
sections.text: Some final consideration should be given to how the nature of the design and delivery of a game can contribute to the application of the metrics referred to in Sections 3.1 and 3.2. Content distribution platforms such as Google Play increasingly allow developers to gain insight into their behavior not only by reaching a broad audience, but also by integrating metrics within the game engine. Taking into account the ethical considerations in Section 3.3, care should be taken to obtain informed consent, but if such mechanisms are in place, it is possible to quickly identify metrics of reach, such as the geographical distribution of players, and impacts, through actions such as game times. However, a more concrete demonstration of the impact in educational or behavioral terms may also require participants to report themselves or agree to have their performance monitored, where mobile platforms in particular can serve a useful purpose by allowing participants to report data on the go, and games can be a means of incentivising and maintaining participation in the research process by, for example, taking part in surveys.

sections.heading: 4. CASE STUDY I: MASELTOV
sections.text: In fact, most people who are able to survive themselves are not able to survive themselves, "he told the German Press Agency in an interview with" Welt am Sonntag ":" I don't think we will be able to change the world. "

sections.heading: 5. CASE STUDY II: THE BEHAVIOURAL ECONOMICS OF ENERGY USE
sections.text: The challenge is that people are able to decide for themselves what they want and what they want.

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: Games provide a rich source of data for user interaction, and their use as research tools is well documented [27], although the need to better integrate the evaluation process into the game as described in Section 2 is only one potential approach. An alternative technique is to record information in a form suitable for externalized analysis, which requires a rich data collection that can be implemented into the game, with users "interactions ranging from individual touch interactions on a mobile device to overarching information such as content preferences and deployment times. This has an appeal from a researcher's perspective, as it has the potential to access data collected during the game to a wide range of analytical tools and techniques. In such an approach, the requirement is not for evaluation to be incorporated into the game as a whole, but for the externalized data to be used to generate feedback that is either communicated through the game itself, or through a broader, mixed learning approach.

sections.heading: 7. ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
sections.text: This work was supported by the European Commission in the framework of the Collaborative Project MASELTOV ("Mobile Assistance for Social Inclusion and Empowerment of Immigrants with Persuasive Learning Technologies and Social Network Services"), which is funded by the European Commission under the eInclusion Theme of the FP7-ICT-7 Grant Agreement No. 288587 project.

referenceMentions.context: Game-based learning has been shown to be effective in a wide range of contexts, including cultural learning [1].
Attempts to incorporate competency assessment in a game-based context have noted the high resource demands in creating competency metrics, though their reusability is of value [2].

A systematic review of literature on the efficacy of serious games noted the diverse range of evaluation methodologies and techniques used, in part a consequence of the diverse range of topic areas and fields to which games have been applied [4].
A further approach to quantitative evaluation specific to the mobile context is presented through Quantitative Evaluation Framework (QEF) [5].

Another quantitative evaluation approach considers the technology acceptance model as its basis [6], building upon the notion of uptake resulting from a combination of perceived usefulness and usability.
"positive" and "serious" aspects of a game [7].

Given the need to balance education and entertainment carefully during the development of a game-based learning solution [8], experience design can offer an approach to understanding both the engaging and educational aspects of a game from an end-user perspective.

[9] note the significance of the "threshold concept" in competency learning, suggesting key transformative points can be defined which result in a step-change in understanding or behaviour for the learner.
outcomes not immediately relatable to assessment metrics [10].
Pandeliev and Becker propose a framework for online evaluation [11], noting the difficulties in applying in-person experimental protocols.
A review of assessment techniques in serious games [12] notes key future research goals to be characterization of players' activity, and better integration of assessment within games.
A study examining gaze in the specific case of a serious game showed not only a difference between genders, but also the ability to correlate the metric to overall performance within the game [13].

Developing digital games requires a game and pedagogical designer: rarely does a single individual possess both skill-sets, and the "tension" [14] between game and instruction requires careful negotiation between the two fields.
implement [15], in particular as individuals can often report subjectively if a game is "fun", though self-reporting of learning, and in particular impact on attitude, can deviate significantly from
objective observations of resultant behaviour [16].

Cultural competency development also poses some unique questions for researchers and developers of gamebased solutions: as we cannot hope to represent the breadth and depth of real-world cultures within the confines of a digital game, how can we distil key principles and identify the "thresholds" [9] at which competencies develop? Empowerment is a common and demonstrably effective approach used in games seeking to influence behaviour [17].
An example of their use to empower hospital patients showed efficacy in a real-world context [17], supporting the view that games can empower the player through a range of mechanisms.

Narrative is one means by which to achieve this [18], as characterization and identification can be utilised as tools by which to transpose real-world problems arising from lack of empowerment, to ones which have identical traits, but are viewed from a different perspective.
Finally, the game seeks to apply an experiential learning paradigm, a common approach in game-based solutions [19, 20].

Kolb's theory of learning through experience [21] has seen much attention from game- and simulation-based learning communities [19, 20, 22].

The game related to risk-taking is based on a Lottery Behavioural Task [24] and will classify people according to their perception towards the changes in probability.
Regarding the second important personality trait, patience, is more complex than risk tolerance since it consists of multiple dimensions [25].

metadata.abstractText: As digital games continue to be explored as solutions to educational and behavioural challenges, the need for evaluation methodologies which support both the unique nature of the format and the need for comparison with other approaches continues to increase. In this workshop paper, a range of challenges are described related specifically to the case of cultural learning using digital games, in terms of how it may best be assessed, understood, and sustained through an iterative process supported by research. An evaluation framework is proposed, identifying metrics for reach and impact and their associated challenges, as well as presenting ethical considerations and the means to utilize evaluation outcomes within an iterative cycle, and to provide feedback to learners. Presenting as a case study a serious game from the Mobile Assistance for Social Inclusion and Empowerment of Immigrants with Persuasive Learning Technologies and Social Networks (MASELTOV) project, the use of the framework in the context of an integrative project is discussed, with emphasis on the need to view game-based learning as a blended component of the cultural learning process, rather than a standalone solution. The particular case of mobile gaming is also considered within this case study, providing a platform by which to deliver and update content in response to evaluation outcomes. Discussion reflects upon the general challenges related to the assessment of cultural learning, and behavioural change in more general terms, suggesting future work should address the need to provide sustainable, research-driven platforms for game-based learning content.
